nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -355,3 +360,58 @@ Lambda Aggregate Functions
         -- (2, 42)
 
     The state type must be a boolean, integer, floating-point, or date/time/interval.
+
+
+Filtering During Aggregation
+----------------------------
+
+The ``FILTER`` keyword can be used to remove rows from aggregation processing
+with a condition expressed using a ``WHERE`` clause. This is evaluated for each
+row before it is used in the aggregation and is supported for all aggregate
+functions.
+
+    AGGREATE_FUNCTION(<expression>) FILTER(WHERE <condition>)
+
+For example, you want to add a condition on the count for Iris flowers,
+modifying the following query.
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT species,
+           count(*) AS count
+    FROM memory.default.iris
+    GROUP BY species;
+    species   |  count
+    ------------+-------
+    setosa     |    50
+    virginica  |    50
+    versicolor |    50
+
+If you just use a normal WHERE statement you loose information:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT species,
+        count(*) AS count
+    FROM memory.default.iris
+    WHERE petallengthcm > 4
+    GROUP BY species;
+    species   | _col1
+    ------------+-------
+    virginica  |    50
+    versicolor |    34
+
+Using a filter you retain all information:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT species,
+           count(*) FILTER (where petallengthcm > 4) AS count
+    FROM memory.default.iris
+    GROUP BY species;
+    species   | count

nodes.bodyText:
The canonical example (and very useful example) is to use FILTER to remove nulls from consideration when using array_agg:
SELECT array_agg(col) FILTER (WHERE col IS NOT NULL)
FROM t

There's no easy way to achieve that, especially when the query involves other aggregations.

+Filtering During Aggregation
+----------------------------
+
+The ``FILTER`` keyword can be used to remove rows from aggregation processing
+with a condition expressed using a ``WHERE`` clause. This is evaluated for each
+row before it is used in the aggregation and is supported for all aggregate
+functions.
+
+    AGGREATE_FUNCTION(...) FILTER (WHERE <condition>)
+
+A common and very useful example is to use ``FILTER`` to remove nulls from
+consideration when using ``array_agg``.
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT array_agg(col) FILTER (WHERE col IS NOT NULL)
+    FROM t
+
+As another example, imagine you want to add a condition on the count for Iris
+flowers, modifying the following query.
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT species,
+           count(*) AS count
+    FROM memory.default.iris
+    GROUP BY species;
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    species    | count
+    -----------+-------
+    setosa     |   50
+    virginica      50
+    versicolor|    50
+
+If you just use a normal WHERE statement you loose information:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT species,
+        count(*) AS count
+    FROM memory.default.iris
+    WHERE petallengthcm > 4
+    GROUP BY species;
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    species    | count
+    -----------+-------
+    virginica  |   50
+    versicolor     34
+
+Using a filter you retain all information:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    SELECT species,
+           count(*) FILTER (where petallengthcm > 4) AS count
+    FROM memory.default.iris
+    GROUP BY species;
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    species    | count
+    -----------+-------
+    virginica  |   50
+    setosa     |    0
+    versicolor |   34
+    (3 rows)
